channel.title: NOVA | PBS
channel.description: NOVA turns its lens on the timeliest developments and most intriguing personalities in science and technology in a new magazine series, NOVA scienceNOW, and we want to hear what you think about it.

item.title: Killer Typhoon
item.description: What made Haiyan so destructive, and how can we prepare for the next monster storm?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Roman Catacomb Mystery
item.description: Who or what killed hundreds of people hidden in a burial chamber nearly 2,000 years ago?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Alien Planets Revealed
item.description: Are we alone—and if not, what might the inhabitants of far-flung worlds look like?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Dutch Windmills
item.description: Explore an 18th century windmill with a modern day Dutch miller.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Ghosts of Murdered Kings
item.description: Bronze age bog bodies reveal the strange beliefs of the long-vanished peoples of Europe.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Zeppelin Terror Attack
item.description: Discover how the first civilian bombing unfolded as Germany’s Zeppelins rained fiery terror on London in World War I.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Judo with Nature
item.description: Planting trees in front of dikes is one way to keep large waves from flooding the shore.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Repairing the Beach After Sandy
item.description: To rebuild the coastline, engineers are pumping sand onto New York's Coney Island beach.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Great Cathedral Mystery
item.description: Master craftsmen explore how Florence’s monumental dome was built nearly 600 years ago.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Reimagining New York
item.description: A risk management expert says that we must look to New York's future to prevent flooding.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: The Shot That Missed
item.description: What happened to the mysterious "first bullet" from JFK's assassination?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Cryonics
item.description: A company called Alcor freezes dead people, hoping to restore them to health one day.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Super Fast Cameras
item.description: A new high speed camera can capture light in motion and see around corners.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Cyber War Games
item.description: A project called DETER allows researchers to practice fighting cyber crimes.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: The Hummingbird Drone
item.description: A new drone doesn't fly like an airplane or helicopter—it flaps its wings like a bird.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Natural Flood Protection
item.description: Could shellfish beds protect New York from flooding?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Making More Stuff Quiz
item.description: Could robots do search and rescue? Can we grow batteries? Take the quiz and find out.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Cockroach Cyborgs
item.description: Scientists are turning cockroaches into robots—and you can, too.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Asteroid: Doomsday or Payday?
item.description: Will future asteroids trigger massive extinctions—or be mined for precious minerals?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: At the Edge of Space
item.description: Can scientists unravel the mysterious phenomena that lurk between Earth and space?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Mushroom Material
item.description: Move over peanuts, there's a new packaging material in town—and it's made of mushrooms.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Floating Buildings
item.description: Engineers in the Netherlands propose building homes that float on water.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Carnivorous Plants, Killer Ants
item.description: Ant eats plant's parasites. Plant eats ant's poop. It's the circle of life.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: RoboBees to the Rescue
item.description: As colony collapse disorder decimates beehives, scientists are developing mini drones, called RoboBees, to help pollinate our crops.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Making Stuff: Faster
item.description: Host David Pogue tries to find out if there are physical limits to how fast we can go.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Making Stuff: Wilder
item.description: Host David Pogue travels the globe to explore new technologies inspired by nature.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Making Stuff: Colder
item.description: Host David Pogue asks if cold holds the key to technology that can improve our lives.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Making Stuff: Safer
item.description: Host David Pogue examines groundbreaking research that aims to keep us out of harm’s way.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Ground Zero Supertower
item.description: Engineers race to complete 1 World Trade Center as they grapple with the final challenges.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Get Involved: Making Stuff
item.description: Discover a range of opportunities for exploring how scientific discovery and engineering lead to innovation.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: 16th Century Nose Jobs
item.description: Thinking about getting a nose job? Thank goodness it's not the 16th century.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Ground Zero Supertower
item.description: Engineers race to complete 1 World Trade Center as they grapple with the final challenges.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Megastorm Aftermath
item.description: How can cities prepare for rising seas and raging storms?
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: Making More Stuff
item.description: Host David Pogue hits the road to explore the frontiers of invention and innovation.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>

item.title: ScienceCafes.org
item.description: Find out about Science Cafés. Their casual, open format readily engages the public in conversations about science.
item.author: NOVA <nova@wgbh.org>
